projects.name: Link Forest
projects.description:
Link Forest is a .NET Core application that acts as a link dashboard, allowing a user to pin their links to categories and organize them effectively.

This application includes a client, login, and administration view, with a working backend holding secure username and passwords.
Editing and deletion of links is done through query routing using the link's unique id. Partial views are used for the navigation bar, banner, and timeout overlay.

This application also has a simple login system, with a table of salted and hashed username/passwords that have access to the admin end of the app.

projects.name: Tech Roster
projects.description:
Tech Roster is a MEAN stack application that records course and technology data, and links them in an adminstrative front end, with a MongoDB run backend.

The front end is built with the Angular 4 framework, and uses routing along with nested components. A service feeds the Express provided MongoDB data to all the components that need it and peripheral components, like the DeletePopup use EventEmitters to communicate their data back to the main components.

While a lot of the styling was provided forma previous project, The technology edit styling and delete popup styling are my own, using the original look and feel as direction.

projects.name: Photo Album
projects.description:
Photo Album is a MEAN stack application that displays images to a user and allows them to provide comments to the images. A thumbnail jumplist gives the user another way to navigate the images.

This application uses nested components with EventEmitters to communicate interactions the user provides, such as clicking a thumbnail, to main components like the gallery image lightbox.
Form validation is achieved using FormGroup and FormControl classes imported from Angular, and backend sanitation also takes place with middleware express-sanitizer.

This was a class assigned project, with pictures and descriptions being provided. Styling was done using sass and flexbox.

projects.name: spritesheetr
projects.description:
A spritesheet building application that uses an intuitive UI to allow a user to upload individual sprite images and manipulate their properties for export.
This project uses Angular 4 as the framework, with the html2canvas library to snapshot the final sprite canvas for export.

This project is still active, and is only partially complete. The end result will hopefully include a spritesheet cutting interface so that a completed spritesheet can be uploaded and manipulated as well.

projects.name: RW Level Editor
projects.description:
Still very much a work-in-progress, RW Level Editor is a web application that is designed to help users build Rain World levels. It was designed out of a desire to have an easier interface to build levels with than the official one that was released to the public.

So far, only the geometry portion of this project has a good amount of work completed. This is a big project.

projects.name: Portfolio Website
projects.description:
This website was created with Angular 4, and populated with JSON data.

Below includes some design mockups made in Adobe Illustrator for what the page layout might look like.

projects.name: Rain World Hunter Tracker
projects.description:
Created out of a need I had to take the ambiguity out of scoring points while playing as Hunter in Rain World.
This application takes a sav.txt file from the game, processes its very human unreadable data, and provides a visual dashboard of your current stats. It hasn't been put through all the QA ringers, but it seems pretty stable in its current form.

Application was built with HTML5, CSS, and vanilla Javascript. It was compiled with Gulp and Babel.

The Rain World speedrunning community uses this app to help determine what their score count might be at any given time during their run.

projects.name: Vue Calculator
projects.description:
Created as part of a self-directed course to learn Vue.js, this calculator was my way of trying to build something logical out of something new to me.
This app is a simple calculator that responds to button click events, keyboard key inputs, and uses class bindings to indicate the current operator. The styling is a combination of Flexbox and CSS grids.

projects.name: Vue Calculator
projects.description:
Similar to the calculator app, except much larger, this app was built to both test my abilities to translate my learning from Angular into Vue.js, and to start the process of building a world-buliding database as a personal project. This app doesn't have full capabilities (yet), but if I can get all the Views and components fully linked to the MongoDB database they are attached to, this could be a very good boilerplate for anyone else wanting to build a MEVN stack database.
To anyone wanting to testing the addition, editing of characters, you can activate this feature by clicking the footer (the inspector console should give some kind of indication), HOWEVER, I have not yet implemented any limitations/security features, so there are many ways to break the system. Please don't. Thank you.

projects.name: Dragon Child Creator
projects.description:
This application was created in Flash when I was looking to try to create a 'Creator' application that would take MovieClip data and figure out how to structure its code without a creative user having to go into an ActionScript3.0 file and fiddle with arrays and numbers.
All the interfaces are custom made, with only the PNGEncode class being imported, as that's a bit above my comfort zone.

projects.name: Leaky Faucets
projects.description:
This was a client project during college where they wanted an interactive game surrounding the idea of teaching users a little bit about water conservation.
My task was the programming; the art was done by other talented individuals.
The game was staged in Adobe Flash Professional, and built in FlashDevelop.

This was my first crack at completing a fully-functional game, with sound, persisting data and all the other fun management that comes with game building.

Team members: Jaclyn Staples, Craig Smith, Colby MacPhail, Ronan Wallebeck, Thomas Webber

projects.name: Bunny Gums
projects.description:
This game was built to be used on Android devices. Made in FlashDevelop as an Adobe AIR application, this game tests your memory reflexes by seeing if you can remember a colour sequence without being given direct feedback on what colours you've already selected.

The concept was neat, but a bit unpolished.

The high score functionality was never fully implemented.
